p.hi: Walter Reed and The Conquest of Yellow Fever.

div1.p: Talk ( given at The University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Vov Nov. 17, 1947 )

At the end of the Civil War, in the fall of 1865, a circuit-riding Meth-
odist minister and his wife moved to Charlottesville so that their sons might im-
prove their education. Their 14 year old boy first went to the Charlottesville
Institute, a boys' day school where. Then, just 80 years ago, in the fall of 1867,
he tried to enter the Academic Department of this University. Although he was
only 16 years old and under the required age, the faculty admitted himWalter Reed, hoping
for the best that he would make good. After one year in the undergraduate school
this boy, Walter Reed, entered the medical school ( X ) and promptly accomplished one
of his first unusual feats. He completed the medical course in a single year, and
on July 1, 1869, as the youngest man ever to earn a medical degree here, he received
his diploma. ( X ) (which I hold in my hand).

Had there been at that time a chapter of The Alpha Omega Alpha Honorary medical fraternity here, Walter
Reed would certainly have qualified for membership. (of course he might not have been elected!) At this later date you are
honoring him by listening today to the story of “Walter Reed and the Conquest of
Yellow Fever.” My story might well have almost been entitled “The University of Vir-
ginia and the Conquest of Yellow Fever,” because as we shall see, twothree other Univer-
sity of Virginia men also played important roles in this drama.

At the close of the Spanish-American War thousands of American soldiers
returned home to be received like conquering heroes ( X ). But others returned
home not so gloriously ( X ). Some returned in hospital ships, The soldiers whose
bodies had been weakened by fever. Some were in coffins ( X ), The soldiers who
had met death at the hands of an enemy more powerful than any Spaniard. For dis-
case, especially yellow fever, had killed more soldiers than had the bullets of
the enemy. Day after day, strong young men became hot with fever and wracked with
__________________________________________________
( X ) slides
X=slide
Hench - 2 - eej
pain; then they turned yellow ( X ), suffered with the dreaded “black vomit” and
died at the rate of as many as 200 a day.

“We'll stop that,” said the United States Government, and with its Army
of Occupation it sent physicians whose duty it was to control yellow fever which
had been endemic in Havana for more than 200 years. Among these physicians were
Major Gorgas, who was responsible for the health of the soldiers and civilians in
the city of Havana, and Major Jefferson R. Kean, ( X ) a graduate of the Univer-
sity of Virginia whose chief responsibility was the health of the American sold-
diers at Columbia Barracks ( X ) on the outskirts of Havana in the little subur-
ban town of Quemados de Marianao, near the famous bathing beach, La Playa.

Despite the vigorous sanitary methods which were instituted, yellow
fever continued to spread, and in May and June, 1900, Major Kean, a worried man,
compiled a tragic list of the names of soldiers and civilians, of fellow-officers
and their wives, all living in the neighboring streets of Quemados and all vict-
ims of yellow fever. The mortality rate among the officers on the headquarters--
staff of Generals Wood and Lee was alarming. The clerks in General Wood's office
( X ) burned on their desks sulfur candles as a prophylactic measure, but the can-
dies burned in vain, and in the officers' mess they drank a gruesome toast, “Here's
to the ones who have gone. Here's to the next one to go!”

One of the earliest to go was Major Edmunds, a friend of Major Kean.
Because General Lee had already lost so many officers and men he ordered all those
not immediately in charge of the sick to stay away from the sick-rooms of those with
yellow fever. Thus Major Kean could not visit Major Edmunds who lay sick unto death
in the front room of this little house ( X ). But on the latest dawn that Major
Edmunds was to see, Major Kean, torn between the conflicting obligations of obed-
ience to his commanding officer and of loyalty to his dying friend, rose about 4 a. m.
Hench - 3 - eej
and went to this little porch where, technically not in the patient's room, he spent
a last few minutes. During that short visit Major Kean was bitten by mosquitoes from
the sick room but thought little of it. But a few days later on June 21 Major Kean
suddenly developed yellow fever.

As if to ridicule the puny efforts of the army medical corps, the disease
was now striking down the physicians themselves: Could nobody stop this evil thing?
What was its cause anyhow? One of the commonest ideas was that the mysterious cause
of yellow fever arose like an evil spirit, a miasma from the tropical swamps. An
Italian physician, Sanarelli, insisted it was due to a special germ which he had dis-
covered. But nobody really knew the cause, and when a person died of yellow fever
his home was often purified by fire to destroy his presumably infected furniture,
clothing and other personal belongings, called “fomites.” Thus hundreds of thou-
sands of dollars worth of military and civilian equipment went up in smoke in an
attempt to control the disease. But it was all in vain.

On June 25, the fourth day of Major Kean's illness, another army physician
( X ) arrived in Havana, rushed to the bedside of his friend, the major, and exempli-
fied in him saw his first case of yellow fever. Later that day this man, Major Wal-
ter Reed met with three others on the veranda ( X ) of the officers' quarters at
Columbia Barracks Post Hospital. The three others were Drs. James Carroll ( X ),
Aristides Agramonte ( X ) and Jesse W. Lazear ( X ), and the four men thus ended
their first day's work as the members of the United States Army Special Yellow Fever
Board.

They first attempted to find Sanarelli's germ in the bodies of those sick
or dead of yellow fever, but this search soon ended in failure. Perhaps after all
no germ was responsible for the disease. Why in Quemados had the disease progress-
ed so erratically down the streets, striking first in one house ( X ), skipping the
next few houses, then hopping around the corner ( X ), rather than crossing the aff-
Hench - 4 - eej
fected street? Another curious fact was noted when Reed, Agramonte and Lazear went
to study an epidemic which broke out among the soldiers at Pinar del Rio. A sol-
dier in a prison cell ( X ) fell sick and died of yellow fever but his cell mates,
exposed to the same food and atmosphere, remained well. Could something have en-
tered between the bars of the open window, struck one man down and gone away?
Could yellow fever be caused by a winged agent? Could Dr. Carlos Finlay be right
after all? ( X ).

For nineteen years this kindly old Havana physician had been trying to
convince his medical colleagues that yellow fever was caused by a common house
mosquito. But nobody believed him, simply because, although he had inoculated ov-
er 100 volunteers with mosquitoes, he hadn't produced a single case of the disease
which other physicians regarded as unquestionably induced or experimental rather than
probably spontaneous. The volunteers were not quarantined and those few who later
developed yellow fever undoubtedly got it in the ordinary way.

When Reed, Agramonte and Lazear returned from Pinar del Rio the Board
decided on August 1st to try to prove or disprove Finlay's theory once and for all.
They visited Dr. Finlay ( X ) who graciously gave all the help he could including
a supply of mosquito larvae of the suspected species. Thereupon a momentous and
heroic decision had to be made because no animal was then known to be susceptible
to yellow fever. Human volunteers were required. Unwilling to ask others to do
what they themselves would not do the Board decided to inoculate each other among
the first. At this juncture Reed was unfortunately ordered to Washington to fin-
ish an important medical report. Carroll and Agramonte ( X ) continued respect-
ively their bacteriologic and pathologic studies and it fell to Lazear's lot to
begin the mosquito work. This was fortunate because he of all the Board was most
sympathetic to the Finlay theory. Indeed for some time Lazear had been trying (so
far unsuccessfully) to prove a relationship between mosquitoes and yellow fever.
Hench -- 5 -- eej
Thus on the very day the Army Board was officially named in Washington, Lazear in
Quemados, Cuba, was catching mosquitoes in the room of a patient with yellow fever
( X ), and (as shown from notes in his laboratory notebook) was examining their
bodies for agents responsible for the disease. ( X ) (summary of note)

Lazear began to breed Finlay's mosquitoes in their little camp labora-
tory ( X ) and then tried to infect them by allowing them to bite yellow fever
patients at Las Animas Hospital ( X ). Between August 11 and 25 these presumably
infected mosquitoes were applied to nine American soldiers including Drs. Lazear
and Pinto, but nothing happened. They all remained well.

( X ) Two days later, on August 27, discouraged and doubting, Carroll
permitted Lazear to inoculate him again. (Note the threefour U. of Va. men in Corn-
well's painting). In a few days Carroll developed a severe and almost fatal att-
ack of yellow fever. On the way from Carroll's bedside Lazear (without the know-
ledge of his colleagues) inoculated a scoffing volunteer soldier ( X ) who “wasn't
afraid of any little old gnat.” When yellow fever hit him six days later this sol-
dier became a very surprised hero whose widow later received his Congressional Med-
al, and a memorial bridge (X) in Grand Rapids, Michigan was named for him .

Having accomplished two very successful inoculations Lazear wrote his
wife ( X ) (September 8): “I rather think I am on the track of the real germ. But
nothing must be said as yet, not even a hint. I have not mentioned it to a soul.”
How right he was, was tragically proven by what happened ten days later, when he him-
self developed the dreaded disease. During his illness Dr. Lazear told two visit-
ors, Drs. Carroll and Gorgas, that a few days before, while feeding his mosquitoes
on yellow fever patients (in this room) at Las Animas Hospital ( X ) a stray mosquito had alight-
ed on his hand ( X ). Lazear had allowed it to take its fill of his own blood.
From the first he was very ill and died September 25, 1900, officially listed as
a victim of “accidental yellow fever” but none the less a true martyr to science.
( X - Telegram). Such is the official version of this tragic incident. But I am
Hench - 6 - eej
about to tell you another version of the affair, one which was kept secret for
forty years, and which was not even known to Dr. Lazear's widow until I was per-
mitted to tell her of it in 1940 through the courtesy of those who revealed it to
me: Walter Reed's colleagues, Generals Truby and Kean, and Dr. Agramonte's daugh-
ghter.

Reed hastened back to Havana (October 4) filled with mingled emotions.
He was greatly depressed at Lazear's death, yet elated that success at last seem-
ed at hand. But he was also confused. Why did the first nine inoculations fail
and the next ones succeed? The second successful case seemed incontrovertible,
having been quarantined at the otherwise fever-free Post Hospital the scoffing
private (Private Dean -- “case XY”) had had no other conceivable source of in-
fection than via the applied infected mosquito. But could one be sure that Carr-
oll's disease had come from the experimental mosquito bite and not from some oth-
er source to which he might have exposed himself while going about town? And how
could Lazear's tragic case be used to prove anything unless somebody knew what kind
of a mosquito had bitten him?

In the side pocket of the uniform blouse which Lazear had recently worn
Lieutenant Truby, ( X ) at that time commanding officer of the Columbia Barracks Post
Hospital, had found a small notebook containing entries about Lazear's experiments.
Reed eagerly studied these and other notes. Herein was the solution of the age-
old mystery, a solution which became crystal clear to the brilliant mind of Walter
Reed. Finlay's mosquito (the culex fasciatus or Aedes Aegypti) could indeed cause
yellow fever but only under certain special conditions: ( X )

(By carefully noting the relative timings of each step in the successful
and unsuccessful experiments it became obvious that patients with yellow fever have
the agent or virus of their disease circulating in their blood only the first three
Hench - 7 - eej
days of their illness; later when they are sicker, even sick unto death, the agent
has strangely disappeared from the blood. Therefore, a mosquito to become “infect-
ed” must bite a yellow fever victim during these first three days. But even then
that “infected mosquito” cannot transmit its deadly load or infect another person
until the virus has had a chance to develop or “ripen,” within the mosquito's
body for at least twelve days.)

omit
in talk

All of the failures of Finlay and of the Board were thus explained:
those volunteers who had not developed yellow fever had either been bitten by
mosquitoes which had really never been infected (having bitten patients too late)
or had been bitten by “infected mosquitoes” which were still temporarily harm-
less because they had not been allowed to “ripen”.

Thus Lazear's little notebook was vitally useful in solving one mystery
but it posed another mystery, for in it Reed found some incomplete entries which
appeared to indicate that Lazear had secretly submitted himself to other experi-
mental inoculations. Reed pondered long over these entries and then concluded
that when Lazear was taken sick he must have worried lest his life insurance be-
come forfeited if it became known that he had deliberately infected himself with
a fatal disease. (Actually this explanation was incorrect; Mrs. Lazear told me
Dr. Lazear left no life insurance.) But did he for some other reason at the last
fateful hour withhold facts to protect his loved ones? Was this why he had told
Gorgas and Carroll that he had been bitten by a stray mosquito at Las Animas? Reed
believed that it was. Having produced two cases of yellow fever and knowing the
danger, Lazear would surely never have allowed a mongrel mosquito to bite him and
vitiate or interrupt his otherwise meticulously controlled experiments. Reed confided his sus-
picions only to two or three colleagues and then decided to permit the official
records to read that Lazear had become accidentally infected while in the per-
Hench - 8 - eej
formance of duty. Having made his quiet and heroic gesture Lazear had sought to
carry his secret to a better world. Out of respect for the unspoken wishes of
their friend, Lazear's colleagues have kept that secret all these years, Reed and
others having carried it to their graves.

In so doing they eminently proved their loyalty to him. But it app-
arently disturbed them to deprive Lazear of a greater fame and in the following
unpublished remarks of Agramonte X I sense a wistful desire to rectify matters.
At a Havana banquet in honor of Drs. Gorgas and Kean in June 1902 Agramonte's
speech contained this tribute: “The one of us who from the very inception of our
work so strenuously believed in the mosquito theory in connection with the prop-
ogation of yellow fever, the one of us who was best fitted by his training in the
line of our investigation to successfully carry out the work, who in fact perform-
ed the first successful inoculation unknown to his co-workers, Jesse W. Lazear, gave
up his life in the pursuit of knowledge which shall immortalize his name. May he
in the Regions of the Unknown find the glory that is his due which so unjustly has
been witheld by man on earth.”

Knowing that a skeptical world would demand more proof than that afford-
ded by these three successful but relatively uncontrolled inoculations, Reed now
conceived, and with Carroll and Agramonte, executed a series of brilliant experiments
which were to write the final chapter of this story. On the advice of Major Kean,
Reed asked General Leonard Wood, Governor General of Cuba for money with which to
set up an experimental camp ( X ) and to pay what Americans and Spanish volun-
teers might be secured. To the lasting credit of General Wood who had himself been
a physician, he promptly granted Reed's request and threw behind Reed all the auth-
ority of the governor's high office.
Hench - 9 - eej

Yellow fever was to be given away free with premiums of $200.00 The
victims could spend the money any way they wanted to -- if they survived; a rather
biglarge if, considering that the mortality rate of epidemic yellow fever was about 40
per cent. But before any paid volunteers were secured two American soldiers, John
R. Kissinger ( X ) and John J. Moran ( X ), the(who latter was a former student at the Medical
School of the University of Virginia) volunteered their services only on condition that they
could do so without pay and in the interests of science. Legend has it that
Major Reed, profoundly affected, rose and said, “Gentlemen, I salute you.” ( X ).
Both Kissinger and Moran told me that actually, the legend is not true, which
Reed's widow and children were sorry to learn from me a few years ago. But as
one writer said, “If Reed didn't salute them, he should have!” The world is still
saluting them with many honors. ( X - X - X - X - X - X - X)

{Congressional medal
{Walter Reed Hosp
{stamps
{Finlay post-marks
{Cornwell painting
{Kissinger & Moran at W & J
{Lazear memorial Bldg

Hench - 10 - eej

A specially guarded and quarantined experimental station named Camp
Lazear was set up in a secluded spot a mile from Camp Columbia ( X ). There
John Kissinger ( X ) bared his arm in this manner ( X ) for the bites of five
infected mosquitoes, and promptly developed the first case of deliberately acc-
cepted and completely controlled experimental yellow fever in history ( X ). G
of this Reed wrote, “In my opinion this exhibition of moral courage has never been
surpassed in the annals of the army of the United States.”

( X ) Then two small specially constructed wooden buildings were er-
ected. The first was called Building Number One or the “Infected Clothing and
Bedding Building,” ( X ). It comprised one room, 14 x 20 feet, had only two
small windows and was heated by a stove to a tropical temperature. Three cots
were set up and into this sweltering room were brought the soiled and foul-
smelling bed clothes of yellow fever victims. Night after night Dr. Robert
Cooke ( X ), (U of Va Med Sch, 1897) and other soldier-volunteers (Folk, Jernegan, Hanberry, Weather-
walks, Hildebrand and England) hung these offensive clothes around the walls
and on their beds, and then lay down to try to sleep on stinking pillows and
sheets soiled with blood and vomitus. Stomachs rebelled, but spirits remained
firm and not one of these volunteers developed yellow fever, simply because there
were no mosquitoes in the room. Thus was exploded the notion that “fomites” carr-
ried the disease.

The second building ( X ) of similar size (Building Number Two or the
“Infected Mosquito Building”) was divided into two parts separated merely by a
wire screen. ( X ). On a cot in one side of this room ( X ), John Moran, (the later
ex-medical student from this University) exposed his body to the bites of fif-
teen loaded mosquitoes let loose in the room. He was in the room only a little
over an hour in all, but promptly developed yellow fever, while other volunteers
Hench - 11 - eej
who stayed long hours on the other side of the screen where there were no mos-
quitoes remained well. (Peas providing not)

Moran took sick on Christmas day. His yellow fever was a wonderful
Christmas gift to Walter Reed and to all the world. A few days later on New
Year's Eve, Reed in a mood of exialtation and humble gratitude to God, wrote his
family a much quoted letter which has become famous ( X ):

“11:50 p. m. December 31st, 1900-- only 10 minutes of the old century
remain. Here I have been sitting reading that most wonderful work -- La Roche
on yellow fever, written in 1853. Forty-seven years later it has been permit-
ted to me and my assistants to lift the impenetrable veil that has surrounded
the causation of this most dreadful post of humanity and to put it on a rational
and scientific basis. I thank God that this has been accomplished during the
latter days of the old century.

-- The prayer that has been mine for twenty or more years, that I might
be permitted in some way or sometime to do something to alleviate human suffering,
has been answered.

12 midnight! -- Hark! There go the 24 buglers, all in concert, sound-
ing “Taps” for the old year! How beautiful it floats on the midnight air ---.”
(I have the original of this letter if you wish to see it)

In the bodies of twelve more American and Spanish volunteers (Benigno,
Fernandez, Presedo, Martinez, Jernegan, Olson, Folk, Forbes, Andrus, West, Han-
berry and Sonntag) yellow fever was produced at will, either through the medium
of mosquito bites or by injections of infected blood or serum. Fortunately all
these volunteers survived, thanks to the excellent care of Dr. Roger Post aAmes (X).
Their problem solved after just eight months of work, the Board disbanded Camp
Lazear on March 1, 1901. Now armed with precious knowledge Gorgas within three
Hench - 12 - eej
months freed Havana of its age old scourge. Later, with this and other knowledge,
he made safe the Isthmus of Panama ( X ) for the passage of the commerce of the
world.
Continue
Hench - 13 - eej

p.hi: Rediscovery of the Lost Camp Lazear

div1.p:
And what became of their battlefield, Camp Lazear? That is the last
part of my story, a part which I think may interest, and perhaps amuse you.

In the spring of 1940 Mrs. Hench and I decided to visit Havana during a
Florida vacation. I wanted to meet Johnny Moran (who had lived in Cuba for years),
Dr. Agramonte's daughter ( X ) and Dr. Finlay's son ( X ). Also I wanted to make
“a sentimental journey” to see the remains of Camp Lazear, take a few photographs
and then return home. But while pursuing this apparently simple objective, certain
interesting complications arose.

Mr. Moran, smiling, genial and gracious, met me at the Hotel Nacional.
We then started out, leaving Mrs. Hench on the hotel veranda. Poor girl, she had
a long wait and during the next ten days, she scarcely saw us at all! ( X ) Mr.
Moran and I drove from the hotel along Calle 23 through Vedado, passed the old
Colon Cemetery, crossed the Almendares River and soon reached Quemados and the
site of old Camp Columbia, now the Ciudad Militar or chief army post of the dist-
rict. ( X ) We visited briefly the fine new military hospital (officially named
The Agramonte General Hospital) on the very site where the old Station Hospital
PLAYA
of Camp Columbia had stood 40 years before. Then we crossed the La Playa rail-
road track just west of the hospital ( X ) at the little Carnino way - Station
and turned northwest 200 or 300 yards along the track until we came to a small
XX
plot of ground enclosed by a low ornamental wooden fence ( X ). In the center of
the plot was a tree X and under the tree a large sign ( X ) which proclaimed that
“On this spot was established El Campamento Lazear where were performed the stud-
ies of the American commission which proved the theory of Finlay, concerning the
transmission of yellow fever by a species of mosquitoes.” Mr. Moran hadn't seen
the spot for 40 years until he had made, a few days before my arrival, a reconnais-
ance tour to locate it for me.
Hench - 14 - eej

For a few minutes we surveyed the historic spot while I took a few snap-
shots. But even as I did so my thoughts were not so much on X the little memorial-
ized plot of ground in front of me as they were on the little single-track rail-
road just about 70 feet behind me . I couldn't get that railroad track out
of my mind. Despite the identifying sign erected with all the authority of the
Sanitary Department of the Cuban Government, I was vaguly uneasy. ( X ) Here
we were just across the railroad track from old Camp Columbia Station Hospital.
Hadn't I read somewhere in Reed's papers that Camp Lazear was established about
a mile from Camp Columbia? Of course, we were a mile or so from the eastern bor-
der of the camp, but we were only a few yards from the western border. Surely,
this was closer to Camp Columbia than I had expected ( X ).

“Where does this railroad spur lead to?” I asked Mr. Moran, “To La
Playa, the famous bathing beach about a mile away,” he replied. The La Playa
railroad track! Surely Reed wouldn't have set up a camp for semi-secret exper-
iments right beside a railroad track patronized by bordscrowds of other pleasure seek-
ers.

“Does the place look right to you, Mr. Moran? Does the lay of the
land jibe with your recollections of Camp Lazear?” Mr. Moran surveyed the scene
again. “I really can't say, Until a few days ago, I hadn't seen it for 40 years
even though I've lived in Havana for yearssince 1928. Of course it is all built up around
here now. But the local and governmental authorities directed usme here.”

I continued: “Somehow it doesn't seem right to me. It doesn't sat-
isfy my mental picture of the ‘secluded spot about a mile from Camp Columbia’,
mentioned in the old army records.” Our conversation was interrupted by the
arrival of a pleasant but inquisitive young Cuban boy who wondered what we
wanted and if he could help us. He identified himself as the employee of the
real estate agent, Mr. Pogolotti, who was selling empty lots in this district.
Hench - 15 - eej
“Where is Senor Pogolotti?” I inquired. “Oh, he doesn't stay around here. He has
an office downtown and leaves me in charge.” I had a sudden inspiration. If this
was Camp Lazear wouldn't it be nice if I could obtain a sizeable limb of the tree
and have it cut up into paper-weights, pen holders etc., to take back home to some
historically minded medical friends? Mr. Moran translated the request of the crazy
souvenir-hunting American and assured the boy that I would be glad to pay for the
wood and the trouble. The boy's reply was unusual and pleasing, “Why not? Limbs
break off and fall down all the time. You might as well out one off. It's all
right with me.”

But then I got cautious. It was all right with him but would it be all
right with his boss, the owner? The boy assured me, “He won't care. Anyhow he
doesn't own this one little piece of land anymore. The government boughtowns it from
him and put up this sign.” So that was it, nobody cared because it was govern-
ment property. As much as I wanted my souvenirs and desired to obtain them without
a lot of governmental red-tape, I didn't want to get into trouble with the Cuban
Government, so I whispered to Johnny Moran, “I'd certainly like a limb right here
and now. But we had better call the thing off and make a date to see Mr. Pogolotti
tomorrow”.

That night in the Hotel Nacional, I burned the midnight oil, Pouring
over Reed's old papers which I had brought along, I found several brief des-
criptions of Camp Lazear. But the precise location of the camp wasn't mentioned
in a single one of the many medical papers of Reed or his colleagues. But in a
reprint of a popular article X written as late as Dec. 1915 by Dr. Argramonte
and published in The Scientific Monthly, I found what I was looking for .
In this obscure article Agramonte had fortunately written: “I was therefore fav-
orably impressed with the seclusion offered by a spot situated a short distance
from the main road, in a farm, named San Jose, belonging to my friend Dr. Ignacio
Rojas of Havana. Major Reed decided upon this place after looking at many others
Hench - 16 - eej
in the neighborhood, so that on November 20th we inaugurated our camp which we
named Camp Lazear ---”.

“A secluded spot on the farm of Dr. Ignacio Rojas”----there was the
place! No mention of any nearby railroad track to La Playa.

X The next morning, at “Campamento Lazear” Mr. Moran and I met our young
acquaintance of the previous day and his boss, Mr. Luis Pogolotti, a charming,
American-educated, English-speaking Cuban. I decided to go after that tree limb
before discussing the authenticity of the site; “a bird in hand”, you know. We
explained the sincerity of our interest and the reason for my unusual request and
Mr. Pogolotti insisted that nobody, including the Cuban Government, would mind if
I chopped off a reasonably small limb, so he dispatched his young man for the
necessary implements. While the boy was gone, I asked Mr. Pogolotti about the
“pedigree” of that particular piece of land. We were indeed most fortunate in
having run across him, because he and his brother had been in the real estate
business in that neighborhood for years. He told me that he and his brother had
owned that section known as Reparto Zamora, a real estate subdivision named after
Father Zamora, a previous owner of the land. Mr. Pogolotti was still selling lots
but had soldtransferred this particular plot to the Cuban Government. Before that, it was
owned by so and so, earlier by so and so. “How far back in the ownership of the
land have you taken me?” I interrupted. He laughed, “Oh, about 100 years.” “But,
how do you know all this so well?” Again Mr. Pogolotti laughed, “Because of a
dispute over property rights. The government insisted they owned a small strip of
land on this side of the railroad. My brother and I insisted the western boundary
of Camp Columbia ended at the railroad tracks. There was a legal dispute and I
traced most carefully all the old deeds back a couple of hundred years”.

I hesitated while framing the $64.00 question, “When, Mr. Pogolotti, was
this owned by Dr. Ignacio Rojas? You failed to mention his name.” Johnny Moran
watched him sharply. “Dr. Rojas? He never owned this place,” Mr. Pogolotti answered
with a ring of authority; “Then this is not Camp Lazear,” I said “Why not?” What
Hench - 17 - eej
What makes you say that?" Mr. Pogolotti looked disturbed. Hadn't he soldtransferred it to
the government as a memorial -- etc? Who was this American, this total stranger
to Quemados who was shattering tradition and history? Mr. Pogolotti continued:
“The government has evidence identifying this as Camp Lazear.” “I don't care,” said I.
“If Dr. Rojas never owned this place, it isn't Camp Lazear. Furthermore, its
character doesn't fit the old official descriptions of Reed, either. If you'll
come back to the hotel, I would like to show you the basis for my doubts”.

By now, Mr. Moran was also quite convinced that “Campamento Lazear”
represented a case of mistaken identity. He urged Mr. Pogolotti to look at my
evidence. and went over completely once again with him the site's pedigree. Mr.
Pogolotti began to weaken, “All I can say is that for 30 or 35 years, to my per-
sonal knowledge this spot has been locally known as the place where American sol-
diers had experimental yellow fever in 1900.” and a few years ago, some Cuban doc-
tors gave the Minister of Health, photographic proof that it was Camp Lazear. Their
old photograph showed one of the little yellow fever shacks right under this tree.
The shack blew down in the tornado of 1926, but the tree remained as a marker for
Camp Lazear".

By now the boy had returned and was whacking away at a lower branch using
a machete, . Seeing he was getting nowhere, I suggested he get a saw. This
seemed to him to be a novel and puzzling idea. Being a reactionary he wasn't con-
vinced of its usefulness and anyhow he didn't have one. After wasting more minutes,
impatiently I gave him some money and sent him to buy a saw. The saw purchased, the
limb was quickly felled and cut into short lengths which we tenderly gathered and
transported to the garage of the local branch of the Sun Oil Company of which Mr.
Moran had been president. So far as I know, the wood is still there.

We left with Mr. Pogolotti's promise to help us find the Rojas farm of
1900, cheered at his parting remark that the rarename “Rojas farm” sounded vaguely fam-
iliar, but he couldn't place it at the moment.
Hench - 18 - eej

The next day, Mr. Moran and I visited the Finlay Institute, a sort of
Cuban Rockefeller Foundation, and met some of the old-time physicians. During
our conversation, I mentioned briefly my vague doubts as to whether Camp Lazear
had been located properly, but those who had any opinion were sure that it had
been properly identified. X In 1926 Dr. Ignacio Alvare, while interning at the
new Columbia Military Hospital, was told by neighbors that a little house fac-
ing the adjacent La Playa railroad track was all that remained of Camp Lazear.
He took a photograph of it and gave it to Dr. Recio. On the basis of this lo-
cal tradition, the government had memorialized the site. . The little
wooden house, presumably one of Reed's experimental buildings, was no longer
there, but the tree remained. Mr. Moran and I obtained copies of this photo-
graph and went back to the tree. It was the same tree all right ( X ) as we
could see from the arrangement of the roots and branches, but if the little
building had been one of Reed's experimental buildings, it had to face either
south or north as described by Reed in official papers. With thea compass, Mr.
Moran and I carefully noted that the little building in the Alvare-Recio photo-
graph had faced east before its destruction; furthermore, the general contour
of the building was not the shape of Reed's buildings as shown in old Army photo-
graphs. ( X ); furthermore, if this little shack (at “Campamento Lazear”) were
authentic, it meant that a railroad would have passed right between Reed's Build-
ings Number One and Two. However, the old Army photograph showed no rail-
road and its presence would have been most incongruous. ( X ) In reconstructing
the various tents and little buildings of Camp Lazear as shown in various Army
photographs, let me show you again the location of Buildings Number One and Two.
Obviously the Alvare-Recio photograph had been misinterpreted and this could not
have been either one of the Reed experimental buildings.
Hench - 19 - eej

The next day Mr. Pogolotti thrilled us by telling us that he had actually
located the San Jose farm. (X) He laughed and said, “I knew that name was vaguely fam-
iliar; as a matter of fact, my brother and I bought part of it from the Rojas fam-
ily a number of years ago and out it up into lots, but the main part remains.” and
we will go there tomorrow." We visited the Finca San Jose on the Calzada Real
(“Royal Street”) of Quemados, and there on the old entrance gate was the signa name plate-,
“San Jose.” . X Inside the grounds was a lovely old home surrounded by tall
palms. We found an elderly niece of Dr. Rojas and after being introduced I
eagerly asked her how long she had lived there. When she said she had lived
there many years, I asked her if she had any recollection which concerninged American
soldiers and yellow fever and Camp Lazear thirty-nine years before. At once,
she said, “Yes, there were American soldiers with a few tents and a couple of
buildings erected on the rear of this farm, but I don't remember that the place
had any special name. I remember, we children had to stay away from the camp
as it was guarded, but my little brother, bolder than I, used to talk with the
guards and got apples and food from them for his little pig.” I asked her if
she would take us to that part of the farm where she believed the old camp had
been. She hesitated, went into to the homehouse and talked in voluble Spanish to a ser-
vant. Mr. Moran suddenly smiled broadly. I asked what was up and he whispered
to me, “She isn't taking any chances with you. She told somebody that she is
going to get into our car with us, presumably to go to another part of the farm,
but if she doesn't return in one-half hour, please come after her. She is af-
afraid you might kidnap her!” I might add that the lady was aboutover fifty years of age and some-
what heavy.

She showed us the place at the rear of the farm where she thought the
camp had been and ( X ) this was confirmed by Madam Rojas whom we visited in a
day or two. She was a lovely lady and was most kind in telling us of her re-
Hench - 20 - eej
collections of the doings of 1900, and went with us from her town house to the Jan
Jose farm and drove around, showing us where the American experimental camp had
been. ( X ) She got out old maps of the farm as it was in 1857 and 1912. ( X )
From time to time parts of the farm had been sold and the remainder comprised a
small estate which they used as a summer home.

( X ) As Mr. Moran and I wandered around the rear of the old farm,
we noticed an old shack comprised of two sections and wondered if it could poss-
sibly be either of Reed's experimental buildings. It certainly did not seem to
be the right shape. (and there were several trees adjacent to it. Old Army photo-
graphs showed no trees adjacent to the Experimental Buildings in 1900. As we were stand-
ing there, as had happened previously, a friendly and curious Cuban came to ask
us what we wanted. He stated that he was Mr. Zunzunegui and that he had been raised
in the little shack but had moved out a couple of years before with his family. When
we asked if he had any recollections of the American soldiers and yellow fever, he
said, “Yes, the American soldiers lived in this building and got yellow fever. My
father told me that.” We could hardly believe him and because of the appearance of
the buildings, frankly we doubted his statement. Later in discussing this with The Rojas's
family they assured us that Mr. Zunzunegui was in error because as they recollected
it, when the American soldiers left they took away the tents and tore down the two
little buildings excepting the floors which the Rajos family used for picnics. De-
spite our mutual doubts I found myself returning again and again to the little shack
and I must have taken at least twenty pictures of it from all angles.

Armed with this information we revisited the Finlay Institute, and also
visited Dr. Moya, a cabinet member in charge of the Department of Health who list-
ened to us politely and referred us to Dr. Ramos, the Secretary of Defense, who as
the former Director of Sanitation, had arranged for the memorializing of El Camp-
amento Lazear. After a preliminary conference, Dr. Ramos arranged for a meeting of
“all concerned.” It was quite a meeting with two cabinet members and secretaries,
Hench - 21 - eej
several members from the Finlay Institute, Johnny Moran and me. At first, they
were inclined to reject our findings rather vigorously. It was suggested that the
disturbing railroad track at Camp Lazear might have been built since 1900, but Mr.
Moran and I had already gotten an answer for that. We had seen Mr. Webster, Chief
Engineer for the Havana Central Railroad, who had looked up the matter and had given
us maps to prove that thisthat particular spur was finished in 1865. When we presentedtred them
this, it was suggested, “After all, suppose you are right. From what you tell us
the true site of Camp Lazear, surrounded by small cheap homes and adjacent to a quarry,
is obviously not a fitting place to erect the memorial buildings we plan to build.
What difference does it make if we erect a memorial to Dr. Lazear where the memorial
sign now stands?” Johnny Moran became indignant and insisted that although they might
honor Lazear at the spot they had chosen, they should not call it Camp Lazear. Af-
ter further meetings and discussions, Dr. Ramos settled the matter by saying, “If we
have erred in the matter, send me a documented report, and I will see what can be
done”.

( X ) This is how matters stood when we ended our visit of 1940. It was
the recollection of the Rojas family that the camp site had been on the rather high
ground of the farm, a little ways fromnorth of the shack of which I had taken so many pictures.
The Finca San Jose certainly filled the bill. It was “a mile from Camp Columbia, in
a secluded spot not far from the main highway” (Calzada Real). ( X ) Later, in Wash-
ington in the photographic files of the Army Museum, I came across an old model of
the Station Hospital of Camp Columbia and lo and behold! the model indicated that
just across the railroad track from the Station Hospital there were two rows of little buildings. At
last these little buildings were identified. They were the little shacks or the
“yellow fever wards” where the first patients with spontaneous yellow fever had been
taken care of and where later the victims of the experimental yellow fever had been
brought from Camp Lazear and had been taken care of by Dr. Ames. Actually therefore,
the site of the false “Campamento Lazear” was well-memorialized as on this spot the brave
Hench - 22 - eej
volunteers had been taken care of and also on this spot the martyr Lazear had died.

( X ) Still later in Mrs. Reed's own scrap book of her husband, I found this
little picture of these little huts which completed the identification.

That fall I was to give an address at the dedication of the Lazear
Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College, Pennsylvania. That spring
before I had left the Rojas family, I had asked if they knew of any letter or rental
contracts between Dr. Rojas and Major Reed. Mrs. Rojas first recollected that the
farm had been loaned free to the American doctors and she knew of no rental records.
But just before the dedication was to be held, I wrote again to Madam Rojas asking
if they had been able to find anything. X To my delight, back came the word that they
had just found the old diary or day book of Dr. Rojas with some entries that would
undoubtedly interest me. The entry of January 2, 1901, stated as follows: (X)
“Collected a check sent by Major Surgeon U. S. V. Major Read, (sic) value $20.00,
covering the first month's rent of the land on the San Jose farm occupied by the
Yellow Fever Commission.” The entry of April 22, 1901, referred to “the rent on
Camp Lezar” (sic) ( X ) Most important of all to me was the entry of October 10,
1901. ( X ) “Today was received the last check of $20.00, amount of the rent for Camp
Lazear on the San Jose farm which became due on the 9th and they left the farm; leav-
ing the two wooden houses which they used to carry out the experiments on yellow fev-
er and mosquitoes.” Mrs. Rojas now recollected that it was the wooden floors of the
tents that they had later used for picnicing and that these two little wooden build-
ings had been there for years until one blew down in the cyclone of 1926.

You can imagine the elation of Mr. Moran and me. ( X ) Later I was to
receive from General Kean the checkbook which he had kept as disbursor for Camp
Lazear. Here you will see the actual check stubs corresponding to the payments made
to Dr. Rojas and others (cost of Camp Lazear project=500000) I could hardly wait to return to Cuba in the spring of 1941. On my arr-
rival Mr. Moran and Itook me immediately went to visit the old house. ( X ) One of the lean-
Hench - 23 - eej
tos built after 1900 had already been removed, but two or three others remained. It
was their presence that had made us doubt the word of Mr. Zunzunegui. ( X ) We care-
fully made many examinations of the interior. Here were the “tonged and grooved
boards” and the “double thickness wood.” Here were the old sliding panel and the
outside shutter, described by Reed. As it should have, the little building faced
exactly south, ( X ) and it measured twenty by fourteen feet. As a matter of fact,
there was a slight, but amusing, discrepancy here-- the little building is slight-
ly lopsidedly about four inches over-sized on two sides. Moran laughingly explain-
ed: “You must remember, it was built by enlisted men in the Quartermaster Corps.
What difference did it make to them if it wasn't exact to the proper inch.”

( X ) The inside of the building was quite unique in construction as Cuban
officials whom we invited to visited the place with us quickly agreed. Most Cuban shacks have no
ceilings; a roof suffices. But this building had not only a roof, but a unique
ceiling, flattened off at the top.

( X ) A clinching point was that in one corner of the ceiling was a hole
where a stove pipe had once been (as shown in the drawing of Agramonte) No Cuban shack contains a stove pipe since cook-
ing is usually done in a lean-to. Mr. Zunzunegui told us that he and his family
had often wondered what the hole for the stove pipe had signified. They had never
used a stove inside the shack proper, during the many years he had lived in it.
( X ) He said that the little outside stove pipe had fallen from the roof sometime
before and had been kicked around by his kids and it might still be there. We hunt-
ed for it and Mr. Moran's eagle eye spotted it right near the little building.

( X ) Here at last were the undoubted remains of Reed's little Building
Number One. Through this very smoke stack the long-held and expensive theory of
(which I hold in my hand)
“fomites” had literally “gone up in smoke”.

Mr. Zunzunegui located for us the site of the Building Number Two. (X) The
wooden floor had rotted because the ground was dampened by a nearby surface-spring.
He had put in a cement floor which was all that remained. In The tornado of 1926 Building Number
(Concrete broken; enough to interfere with growth of corn)
Hench 24- eej
Two had blown down and for quite awhile it had remained on its side. The neigh-
borhood children used to get on top and slide down the sloping roof. Because this
was dangerous, areMr Zunzunegui finally cut it up for kindling wood. X We carefully measured the distance
from Building Number One to the cement floor of Building Number Two. Reed had
stated that the two buildings were about 80 yards apart. According to our measure-
ment, it was 82 yards. One more thing, you remember the old Army photo-
graph that showed the ruins of an unidentified building just to the (photographic) right of Build-
ing Number Two. Although now somewhat smaller, the ruins still remained.

div1.p:
( X ) In summary, here is the way Camp Lazear now appears. in 1941. The re-
mains of Building Number One are on the right. The old floor of Building Number Two
on the left. The tents were in the center background, and between Buildings Number
One and Two lies the “little valley” which Reed mentioned in his records. ( X ) To
show you a final map of the neighborhood: here in the rear of Finca San Jose is the
remains of Camp Lazear, a mile from the old Station Hospital. Just at the left (west) and
across the La Playa railroad tracks from the old Station Hospital lies the marker of the false
Campamento Lazear, (actually the spot where the soldiers were taken care of as soon as
their experimental yellow fever developed at Camp Lazear.)

( X ) The last two slides show that IMr Moran d and I have finally triumphed, because on
my second visit, I found that the Cuban government was no longer interested in the spot
where the false camp had been marked. The sign was down; part of the fence was
gone, and a cows werewas grazing under the tree. ( X ) Just this year (April 1947) the Cuba govern-
ment finally made the true site of Camp Lazear and our little building a “National
Monument.” Although they have done this, no money has been set aside for its preser-
vation and some of us in this country are trying to raise money to do this.
Hench - 25 - eej

In continuing my investigations I have had unusual luck. Miss Laura
Wood of New York and I found, and I helped to identify in the New York Academy of Medicine
one of the lost Lazear-Reed laboratory notebooks. I had spent considerable time
hunting for the original fever charts which were not to be found anywhere in Wash-
ington. I finally located them in Atlanta, Georgia in the home of Mrs. Ames, the widow of the doctor
who had taken such good care of the soldiers during their experimental yellow fever.
Mrs. Ames, now living in Atlanta, Georgia, graciously added these fever charts to
my collection. General Kean located one of the original contracts between Reed and
one of the volunteers which had been stolen from his office in the Army Medical Mus-
eum. It was found many years later and recently presented to me. In an attic of a
lovely old home outside Baltimore at “Windsor,” the old family home of the Lazears, I
found a trunk full of letters, photographs and other items concerning Lazear and his
mother, including one hundred forty letters sent by Lazear to his mother from Cuba
and elsewhere. Miss Seth, Lazear's cousin, gave all this material to me. Lazear's
son and daughter now live in San Francisco and presented me with one of Lazear's two
microscopes, through which he vainly sought the organisms of yellow fever. The Reed
family have made me the repository of all their data, Congressional Medal, scores of
letters written by Major Reed from Cuba to his wife, describing the day to day ex-
periments, etc. Dr. Howard Kelly who wrote the first book on Major Reed, has pre-
sented all his data to me and Generals Kean and Truby have presented a mass of data
that are in my possession only as caretaker, and steps have been taken for its per-
manent care for the benefit of historians and others.

And so, Building Number One still stands sleeping and creaking in the Cuban sun. For
all I saw ofknow, Mrs. Hench during our two Cuban vacations, she may still be waiting for
me on the porch of the Hotel Nacional, but I hope not creaking and sleeping in the
Cuban sun!

In these days with “the world so lately red with blood and when man's in-
humanity to man is still so pathetically apparent, it is well for us to note the ex-
ample of these men who banded together for high adventure, not to kill or even to die
for one country, but to die, if need be, for their fellowmen of all countries. It is
such as they who reassure us of the inherent decency and dignity of man”.
